_desc.NAICS_DESCRIPTION: Urethane and Other Foam Product (except Polystyrene) Manufacturing

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.  Accidental release prevention and emergency response policies.



The Premier Foam plant believes the health and safety of its employees and the protection of the natural environment, is the utmost concern in the operation of its business.  We are committed to operating and maintaining all of our processes in a safe and responsible manner.



It is our policy to:



Comply with all applicable laws, regulations, and standards.  Review and assess our operations for the purpose of making health, safety & environmental improvements.



We use a combination of prevention programs and emergency response planning, which are described later in this document, to help ensure the safety of our employees and the public as well as protection of the environment.  Our General Manager has the overall responsibility for ensuring that our facility operates in a safe and reliable manner.  This responsibility includes overseeing the implementation of the elements of our risk management program.  To ensure that our risk management program is appropriately developed and implemented, our General Manager is assigned the role of RMP Coordinator and has the background, training, and experience necessary to manage the program.  The RMP Coordinator, acting with the authority delegated as the General Manager, is responsible for coordinating the development, implementation and integration of the RMP elements as is required under Section 68.15 of the RMP rule.



2.  The stationary source and regulated substances handled.



The primary purpose of Premier Foam plant is to produce flexible polyurethane foam for bedding and furniture applications.  The foam is made by high-shear mixing of chemicals as they are poured on a conveyor.  The conveyor pulls the reacting mixture away from the mixhead.  The foam rises and reacts to make flexible polyurethane foam buns.



Toluene Diisocyanate (TDI), which is regulated by EPA's Risk Management Program rule, is one of the reactants required to manufactur

e polyurethane foam.  TDI is received at the plant by tanker truck and is stored in a storage tank located within concrete containment walls.  The TDI is transferred to the foam process by pump.



The maximum amount of TDI stored on-site is 384,975 lbs. (37,854 gal.)



3.  Off-site consequence analysis scenarios



EPA's RMP rule requires that we provide information about the worst-case release and alternative release scenario's for our facility.  The following are brief summaries of these scenarios, including information about the key administrative controls and mitigation measures to limit the exposure distances for each scenario.



In accordance with the RMP rule and EPA General RMP Guidance Chapter 4: Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA), the Areal Locations of Hazardous Atmospheres (ALOHA) version 5.4.7 was used to determine the distance to the toxic endpoint.  Based on facility parameters and OCA results, the facility is considered Program 1 and only the worst-case release scenario will only be discussed.



Worst-case Release Scenario

Catastrophic failure of the storage tank full of TDI, discharging its entire contents of 384,975 lbs. to the secondary containment.   The free surface area within the diking is 1,424 sq. ft.  The TDI temperature was assumed to be 90F and the ambient temperature was 106F. The ALOHA model was used to estimate the endpoint concentration of 0.007 mg/L as prescribed by Appendix A to Part 68 0.026 miles, or 45 yards.  There are no public receptors within this boundary.



ALOHA modeling assumptions including inputs and results are included as an appendix. A figure showing release endpoint is maintained at the facility.  



4.  The general accidental release prevention program and the specific prevention steps.



We take a systematic, proactive approach to preventing accidental releases of chemicals.  We have an established TDI Control program that outlines the hazards of handling TDI and the controls, which are in place to reduce

the hazards of TDI exposure to the employees, the community and the environment.



5.  Five-year accident history



The Premier Foam plant has not had any TDI releases that qualify for listing in the EPA's required five-year accident history report.



6.  The emergency response program.



We maintain a TDI-specific Emergency Response Plan and a Safety Manual which includes emergency response actions consolidating the various federal, state and local regulatory requirements for emergency response planning.  Our program provided essential planning and training for effectively protecting workers, the public and the environment during emergency situations.  We have coordinated our program with the local fire department with an initial inspection on process startup and annual Tier II submittals.  The LEPC and SERC is the Coweta County EMA and coordinates with the fired department.  A representative group from the fire department routinely visits this plant to discuss how to respond to a release of TDI.  We have also given local hospitals information regarding medical treatment for exposure to TDI.
